The Act is titled "Stop the Sequester Job Loss Now Act" and includes sections on budget process amendments, protecting veterans programs, agricultural savings, and oil and gas subsidies. The Act titled "Stop the Sequester Job Loss Now Act" includes sections on budget process amendments, protecting veterans programs, agricultural savings, and oil and gas subsidies. It also addresses limitations on deductions for oil and gas companies, foreign tax credit rules, a fair share tax on high-income taxpayers, and a bipartisan approach to deficit reduction. The Act "Stop the Sequester Job Loss Now Act" includes budget process amendments, veterans programs protection, agricultural savings, and oil and gas subsidies. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 involve reducing deficit by $27.5 billion for fiscal year 2014 and adjusting defense and nondefense function reductions for 2014. Amendments to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 involve changing the year from 2013 to 2014 and from 2014 to 2015 for discretionary reductions. The savings from the enactment of title II will achieve the savings that would have resulted from sequestration under section 251A for fiscal years 2013 and 2014. SEC. 102 repeals a section of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 201 extends agricultural commodity programs for one year, excluding direct payment programs. The extension of authorities from the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 will continue until September 30, 2014, excluding direct payment programs for covered commodities and peanuts. The section under the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 (7 U.S.C. 7953) will take effect on the earlier of the enactment of the Act or September 30, 2013. TITLE III--OIL AND GAS SUBSIDIES

SEC. 301. LIMITATION ON SECTION 199 DEDUCTION FOR OIL, NATURAL GAS, OR PRIMARY PRODUCTS. SEC. 301 limits the deduction for oil, natural gas, or primary products under section 199. SEC. 302 prohibits major integrated oil companies from using last-in, first-out accounting. The amendment to Section 472 of the Internal Revenue Code prohibits major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method for taxable years ending after December 31, 2013. Taxpayers affected by this change must initiate and implement a new accounting method. The amendment requires taxpayers to make accounting method changes with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. The adjustments needed under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be spread out over a period of up to 8 taxable years. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for major integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The amended Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code introduces special rules for major integrated oil companies classified as dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers are defined as individuals who pay income tax to a foreign country or possession of the United States. The amount paid must adhere to applicable regulations and not exceed the determined limit under subparagraph (B). The amended Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code introduces special rules for major integrated oil companies classified as dual capacity taxpayers. These taxpayers are individuals subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States and receive a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to income taxes generally imposed under the laws of a foreign country or possession on income derived from conducting a trade or business within that country or possession. The amendments made by this section to Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code specify exceptions for taxes that do not apply to dual capacity taxpayers or citizens/residents of a foreign country. The effective date for these amendments is for taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, with provisions to uphold contrary treaty obligations. TITLE IV--THE BUFFETT RULE

SEC. 401. FAIR SHARE TAX ON HIGH-INCOME TAXPAYERS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to add a new part for a Fair Share Tax on high-income taxpayers. The Fair Share Tax on high-income taxpayers imposes an additional tax for a taxable year based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding a certain dollar amount. The Fair Share Tax imposes an additional tax on high-income taxpayers for a taxable year, calculated as the excess of the tentative fair share tax over the sum of regular tax liability, tax imposed by section 55, and payroll tax, minus allowable credits. The tentative fair share tax is 30% of the excess of the taxpayer's adjusted gross income over the modified charitable contribution deduction for the taxable year. The modified charitable contribution deduction is calculated based on the ratio of itemized deductions allowable under section 170 for the taxable year. The modified charitable contribution deduction is determined based on the ratio of itemized deductions allowable under the regular tax for the taxable year. If an individual does not itemize deductions, the deduction is zero. A high-income taxpayer is defined as someone with an adjusted gross income above a certain threshold. The adjusted gross income threshold for high-income taxpayers is $1,000,000, with a 50 percent limit for married individuals filing separately. This amount is subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years beginning after 2014. The adjusted gross income threshold for high-income taxpayers is $1,000,000, with a 50 percent limit for married individuals filing separately, subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2014. Amounts adjusted under subparagraph (A) are rounded to the next lowest multiple of $10,000. Payroll tax is calculated as the excess of taxes imposed on the taxpayer under specific sections over the deduction allowable under section 164(f) for the taxable year. For estates and trusts, adjusted gross income is computed as described in section 67(e). The tax imposed under section 59B is not considered tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes, such as determining credits under this chapter or for section 55. Additionally, a conforming amendment was made to section 26(b)(2) of the Code. Title V of the document discusses the "Sense of the House" on the need for a fair, balanced, and bipartisan approach to long-term deficit reduction. The amendments made in Part VII regarding the Fair Share Tax on High-Income Taxpayers will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2013. The House emphasizes the need for a balanced, bipartisan approach to deficit reduction, rejecting sequestration as harmful. It suggests replacing the 10-year sequester with a plan that increases revenues without burdening middle-income Americans, reduces long-term spending, and protects vital programs while investing in education and research. The House proposes replacing the 10-year sequester with a plan that increases revenues, reduces long-term spending, and protects vital programs while investing in education, science, research, and critical infrastructure for global competitiveness.
